subject: control: command line tool to retrieve fan status (set/resume functions)
commitMessage:
control: command line tool to retrieve fan status (set/resume functions)

This is part three of a multipart commit to create a fan control command
line utility to report service status, show target/actual RPM/PWM info,
and manually control single fans. This commit contains the set/resume
commands. Further functionality will come in subsequent commits.

The resume command is a shortcut to start phosphor-fan-control@0 systemd
service, since most workflows require stopping it to allow control of
individual fans. Once manual intervention is done, it can be resumed.

root@p10bmc:~# systemctl stop phosphor-fan-control@0.service
root@p10bmc:~# fanctl resume
root@p10bmc:~# systemctl status phosphor-fan-control@0.service
root@p10bmc:~# <output indicates service is running>

For set/get functions, here is a usage example:

root@p10bmc:~# fanctl set 10000
root@p10bmc:~# fanctl set 2000 fan1 fan3_0
root@p10bmc:~# fanctl get

TARGET SENSOR    TARGET(RPM)   FEEDBACK SENSOR   FEEDBACK(RPMS)
===============================================================
fan0_0                 10000            fan0_0            10000
                                        fan0_1            13591
fan1_0                  2000            fan1_0             1991
                                        fan1_1             2000
fan2_0                 10000            fan2_0            10000
                                        fan2_1            13591
fan3_0                  2000            fan3_0             1991
                                        fan3_1             2000
fan4_0                 10000            fan4_0            10000
                                        fan4_1            10091
fan5_0                 10000            fan5_0            10000
                                        fan5_1            10021

Signed-off-by: Mike Capps <mikepcapps@gmail.com>
Change-Id: Ib2b2f7433701e0178fcb8d2223e452b541ea5b0c

seems that I'm going to be fighting with clang-format here to get the spacing right. might have to put these in individual cout statements unless there's a clang-format-ignore-this directive.
did you mean to remove fanctl?

Usually with Linux tools I've seen two ways to specify one or more values:
* Has option flags that you can specify more than once: --fan fan3 --fan fan4 --fan fan5
* Allows you to specify a list of tokens: --fans fan3 fan4 fan5

It seems kind of unusual to require the user to specify the list as single command line token via double quotes ("fan3 fan4 fan5").  However, I wasn't part of the design discussion, so if that is how Matt wants it to work or how the shell script worked (and compatibility is a requirement) feel free to ignore this comment.
Ack
Nit: random blank line?
Done
Done
cerr.  Same comment for other error messages being printed.
Done

std::move() is used when you want to move a heavy-weight object that contains resources, such as a string or vector that owns a bunch of memory.  std::move() casts the argument to be an r-value, so that the move ctor or move assignment operator is used to move (rather than copy) the object's resources to the destination object.

int64_t is just an alias for a built-in integer type like 'long int' or 'long long int' depending on CPU architecture.  It has no resources, so no need to move it.
Done

It's required for the interface. Without move() I get fanctl.cpp:432:46: error: cannot bind rvalue reference of type ‘long long unsigned int&&’ to lvalue of type ‘uint64_t’ {aka ‘long long unsigned int’}

Sorry, I didn't look at the declaration of SDBusPlus::setProperty().

You are right it is defined to take a Property&& for the last parameter.  I'm not sure why it is defined that way.

Please disregard my suggestion.
This seems a little confusing.  If I understand things correctly, systemd isn't controlling the fans.  It is just being asked to restart the phosphor-fan-control app, right?
Done

It might be a bit more user-friendly if you printed something like:

"Unable to start fan control service: " << e.what()
Done
As mentioned in another review, I don't think we want all output going to cerr, only error output.
Done
Matt had mentioned the need to remove references to the script and issue.
Done

Nit: Would be easier to read if the SOURCES, LDADD, and CXXFLAGS lines were in the same order as phosphor_fan_control.  Then you can check which things are the same/different easier.  For example, if something about the bitbake environment changes and a new lib must be added, can more easily check which libs each currently has.
Done
Is this used anywhere?
Done
If this could be RPM or PWM, should it be renamed to something like target or targetSpeed instead?
Done
Do these still have to be enclosed in double quotes?  Or can it be a simple list now?
Done
Was this change intended?  Seems like the constant should be used?
Done
Hrm... no example of when you should use this resume option?
added it in the commit msg

ps43 - "Resume running phosphor-fan-control" - Ah! That is better.
-----
What? Where?
"This commit contains the set/resume commands."
Okay, there is a resume command.

root@p10bmc:~# fanctl set 10000
root@p10bmc:~# fanctl set 2000 fan1 fan3_0
root@p10bmc:~# fanctl get
Okay, some get and set examples. What does resume do?
It was actually in the reload() function commit msg. whoops. I moved it to this commit.

What happens if the service is already running? Do we get the exception below or a different type of error message?

I think we should handle the case where the `resume` is given but the service is already running by checking the service's state prior to attempting to start...providing some sort of message back to the user that fan control is already running. Reason for this is if they already ran `resume`, forgot they did, and then try and `resume` again.

It handles resume fine when fan-control is already running. It does emit an exception if you try to reload() while it's not running, however:

root@p10bmc:~# /tmp/build/fanctl reload
/tmp/build/fanctl failed: DBus method failed: org.freedesktop.systemd1 /org/freedesktop/systemd1 org.freedesktop.systemd1.Manager KillUnit
Ack

It doesnt appear that this is optional:

```
root@p10bmc:~# ./fanctl set 5000  
Requires at least 2 options used and only 1were given from [target,fan list,-h,--help]
Run with --help for more information.
```
the final fix for this is in the last commit. However there was another bug that was found and fixed in the latest changeset.
It appears there's no difference between ps38 and ps39.
I back-ported the fix to this commit. the pathMap["speed"] should be pathMap["tach"],
ok, but that doesnt fix this issue that `fan list` is optional does it?
Done

Looks like resume is missing?

```
root@p10bmc:~# ./fanctl resume
A subcommand is required
Run with --help for more information.
```
Done

Patrick is coming thru and updating all exceptions caught to be const, so maybe you should just do a follow-up commit in the fanctl chain to update all exceptions caught to be const.

catch (const phosphor::fan::util::DBusPropertyError& e)

i.e.) https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-fan-presence/+/47524
Done
